data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recognize</kanji> or <kanji>acknowledge</kanji>, so the verb also means <vocabulary>to acknowledge</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to recognize</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to perceive</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to admit</vocabulary>, among others.

This can be used to mean recognizing somebody or something visually, as well as in the sense of "to acknowledge" or "to admit". So you can use this verb to recognize someone's presence, achievements, marriage, or your own defeat. That said, you'll usually see <ja>認める</ja> in the sense of "to acknowledge".

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>surpass</kanji>, but this verb is intransitive, meaning we’re not focussing on who did the action, but on the action itself. So this means <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary>, as in “the storm passed”, <vocabulary>to be over</vocabulary> as in “winter’s over”, or <vocabulary>to be too much</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In order for the storm <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary> you’re going to have to <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>す</ja>) it. Sadly storms won’t pass unless you take legal action these days.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that using <ja>価</ja> for <ja>あたい</ja> is uncommon in modern Japanese. It’s more commonly written in kana or with the <ja>値</ja> kanji.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Okay, this is a great <vocabulary>value</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>price</vocabulary>. Wait, what is? <reading>A tie</reading> (<ja>あたい</ja>). Get a tie, and it will make you more professional which will help you to get a better job. Great value, right there, just for a tie.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>large</kanji> <kanji>force</kanji> is a group of people. Just think about when this word was probably made up... a long time ago, and the biggest force you could have was a huge group of people. This group of people force is also known as a <vocabulary>crowd</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>a large number</vocabulary> of people.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>大</ja> is the <ja>おお</ja> reading (like <ja>大きい</ja>). Nothing you can do about that but remember it. Then, <ja>勢</ja> is rendaku'd to become <ja>ぜい</ja>. Also something you'll just have to remember. Say this word a few times in your head, then you'll be able to come up with an idea of what sounds right and what sounds wrong so that you can figure it out next time this word comes up.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>value</kanji> is a <vocabulary>value</vocabulary>, but only in the mathematical sense.

Depending on the reading, this can also mean <vocabulary>price</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Imagine a numerical <vocabulary>value</vocabulary> written on <reading>a tie</reading> (<ja>あたい</ja>). Now imagine that it’s the <vocabulary>price</vocabulary> of a <reading>ne</reading>igh (<ja>ね</ja>) from your favorite horse. It’s a pretty high price, but you’ll do anything to hear that horse neigh.

Generally, <ja>あたい</ja> refers to a numerical value in math, while <ja>ね</ja> is a formal word for “price.”

Both <ja>準備</ja> and <ja>用意</ja> mean "preparation," but <ja>準備</ja> means preparing in advance for an event, whereas <ja>用意</ja> implies taking appropriate measures. So, <ja>準備</ja> is better for planning a party, while <ja>用意</ja> fits well when making sure you have enough snacks for your guests.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stretch</kanji>, and the verb version means <vocabulary>to stretch over something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to spread out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be taut</vocabulary>, not to be confused with the type of stretching you do after a workout.

This word is both transitive and intransitive. When it follows <ja>を</ja>, it emphasizes the physical act of extending something over an area, like stretching a canvas over a frame, unfurling a sail on a ship, or roping off a crime scene. When following <ja>が</ja>, it expresses the resulting state of having been stretched or spread, like a bloated stomach, a swollen muscle, or a spider web.

This has to do with carrying something literal, unlike <ja>担う</ja> which is not necessarily literal (you'll learn it later). And in this case, you carry it on your shoulder(s). You can remember that it's literal from the reading mnemonic, which has you carrying literal cats on your shoulders.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you celebrate something, you have to yell out your celebrations. Yell out <ja><reading>いわう</reading></ja> three times! It's kind of like a combination of the word <ja>いい</ja> (good) and "wow." <ja>いい</ja>wow! <ja>いい</ja>wow! Just make sure the <ja>いい</ja> gets shortened, because it's getting combined.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It shares its reading with the word <ja>備える</ja>, which you learned a level ago, but in case you need a reminder, here it is:

data.reading_mnemonic:
The readings for this one are the kun'yomi readings of each kanji. <ja>子</ja> is just <ja>こ</ja>, like the individual vocab word. <ja>供</ja> is <ja><reading>ども</reading></ja>, however. Remember this by thinking how much <vocabulary>children</vocabulary> love <reading>domo</reading>-kun.

Also, <ja>子ども</ja> is kind of more "politically correct" with the kana hanging off there. <ja>子供</ja> is still used in a lot of situations, usually stiff ones. The second kanji means servant, and some people don't like that. The second version pops up a decent amount, so it's good to be familiar with that as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how <ja>割る</ja> is "to divide"? Now you're learning the intransitive version. Instead of you doing the dividing, something just gets divided or split up. So this is <vocabulary>to be divided</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be split</vocabulary>.

It can also mean <vocabulary>to break</vocabulary>, as in <ja>ワイングラスが割れる</ja> (the wine glass breaks). After all, when an object breaks, it’s divided into parts, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is shared with <ja>割る</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>scroll</kanji>. But, you don't "to scroll." What do you do to scrolls, though? You roll them up, making this word "<vocabulary>to roll</vocabulary>."
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you are rolling up is your <reading>ma</reading> (<ja>ま</ja>). She's going wild again, so you throw her into a blanket and roll her up to hold her down.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>search</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to search for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to seek</vocabulary>.

Curious about the difference between <ja>捜す</ja> and <ja>探す</ja>? While there is some overlap between the two, <ja>捜す</ja> is typically used in official, thorough searches for something or someone that is thought to concretely exist and has disappeared or cannot be easily found. In contrast, <ja>探す</ja> can also be used for personal searches for things that one desires or is looking for.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're searching all around for a "<reading>sagger</reading>" (<ja>さが</ja>) on your body. This is a flap of skin that is sagging on your body really far, and you probably should get it removed.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've learned that the kanji <ja>絞</ja> means <kanji>strangle</kanji>. <ja>絞る</ja>, on the other hand, means <vocabulary>to wring out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to squeeze</vocabulary> something like a towel, or <vocabulary>to narrow down</vocabulary> ideas.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hide</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hide something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to conceal something</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Hide your <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>)! You have a ton of roosters but you don't want people to know about them, so you gotta hide your cocks. What did you think I was talking about?

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>hide</kanji> away but you're <kanji>alive</kanji>. You've lived your life, so now it's time to hide and enjoy your <vocabulary>retirement</vocabulary> by making your <vocabulary>retreat</vocabulary> from working life.

This word refers to life after someone retires, and usually implies being retired from active life and having a quiet, maybe even secluded, lifestyle. It can also imply handing over the reins to your successors. The word is a little old-fashioned, but you'll still see it in modern writing.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hang</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hang something</vocabulary>. This is when you hang something, like a picture. You can remember this because you don't really <reading>care</reading> (<ja>ける</ja>) about where you hang it, as long as you're the one to do it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>replace</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to replace</vocabulary>. You know that you're doing the replacing because of the <reading>air</reading> (<ja>える</ja>). You're replacing the air as quickly as you can because if you don't you wouldn't be able to breathe in this small room.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>replace</kanji>, and this word means <vocabulary>to be replaced</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be substituted</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to be switched</vocabulary>.

This verb is intransitive, meaning it doesn't take a direct object. You'll sometimes see it with the particle <ja>を</ja>, though, because the <ja>を</ja> is showing a "path" rather than a direct object in this case.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You already know how <ja>可能</ja> means possible. So when you add <kanji>not</kanji> it becomes <vocabulary>impossible</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read <ja>可能</ja> first as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ability</kanji> is there, so it is <vocabulary>possible</vocabulary>... wait, there's enough ability to make this <vocabulary>possible</vocabulary>? Let's do it!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Know how <ja>非難</ja> is a criticism? Make it a verb and you have the word <vocabulary>to criticize</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, it will be really helpful to know the word <ja>非難</ja> to start.

context_sentences.en: I don't want to criticize you, but this is just terrible.
context_sentences.ja: 君を非難するつもりは全くないんだけど、これはひどすぎるよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how <ja>嫌い</ja> is to <kanji>dislike</kanji>? When that dislike is <kanji>big</kanji>, you really dislike it. That means you <vocabulary>hate</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>really hate</vocabulary>) it.

As with <ja>嫌い</ja>, a more literal translation is <vocabulary>detestable</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading for <ja>大</ja>, and the reading for <ja>嫌い</ja> is like the one you learned with <ja>嫌い</ja> in level 20.

context_sentences.en: What food do you really hate?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen how <ja>倒す</ja> is "to knock over." But this is when something gets knocked over by itself. You know that you're not doing anything here, because when you're not touching all these fine glass items, it's very <reading>rare</reading> (<ja>れる</ja>) that anything gets knocked over (because you're not touching anything, you clumsy dumsy). It's also when you or someone else collapses. You didn't push yourself over, you just kind of fell by yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same like <ja>倒す</ja>. If you knew <ja>倒す</ja> you will know the reading of this one too.

context_sentences.en: When I woke up, a tree had fallen in front of my house. It was probably toppled by the wind.
context_sentences.ja: 起きたら家の前に、木が倒れていたんです。おそらく風で倒れたんでしょうね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>飛ぶ</ja> is to fly? Well this word is for when you make some thing fly. So, this word is <vocabulary>to let something fly</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to send something flying</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>to skip over something</vocabulary>, such as someone's turn or a question on a test.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading is just like <ja>飛ぶ</ja>, so if you know that reading you're close. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the second part:

You can use your strength <vocabulary>to let something fly</vocabulary>, and that something is a <reading>bus</reading> (<ja>ばす</ja>). You're that buff!

context_sentences.en: Fugu sent a triple flying over center field.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Like with <ja>確か</ja>, which means <kanji>certain</kanji>, this is the verb version of that. So when you "do certain" you are going <vocabulary>to make sure of</vocabulary> something or you're going <vocabulary>to verify</vocabulary> something.
data.reading_mnemonic: This one is kun'yomi followed by okurigana. If you remember the reading you learned with <ja>確かに</ja>, you should know this one!

context_sentences.en: You should make sure the door is properly locked.

context_sentences.en: Verify that the alcohol content has been completely removed.

context_sentences.en: Kanae always checks the dictionary to make sure there are no mistakes in word use.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something is a trouble (<ja>面倒</ja>) and it is smelly (<ja>臭い</ja>). So what is something that's smelly and a trouble? Well, something that's <vocabulary>troublesome</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a bother</vocabulary>, I suppose. Basically you can ignore the smelly part. For some reason someone threw that back in, but smelly things are a bother, I suppose.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the words <ja>面倒</ja> plus <ja>臭い</ja> added together. Just make sure you know those words and you'll know this one too!

context_sentences.en: Taking a shower every day is such a bother.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>検査</ja> is inspection, so the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to inspect</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know <ja>検査</ja> already as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>raise</kanji>, and this verb is when you do that to something. It's transitive. So this means <vocabulary>to raise something</vocabulary>. It actually has a pretty wide meaning, and can also mean "raise" in the sense of <vocabulary>to cite something</vocabulary>, like an example. It can even mean <vocabulary>to hold something</vocabulary>, like an event.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>挙がる</ja>, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.

context_sentences.en: When I call your name, please raise your hand.

context_sentences.en: If I cite examples, it will be endless.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>理解</ja> is understanding, so the verb version would be...? How about <vocabulary>to understand</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to comprehend</vocabulary>? Well, do you?
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, if you know <ja>理解</ja> already this one is easy <vocabulary>to comprehend</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>批判</ja> is <kanji>criticism</kanji> so the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to criticize</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will be much easier to read this if you know <ja>批判</ja>, as well.

context_sentences.en: My boyfriend gave me a hard candy after harshly criticizing me.
context_sentences.ja: 私の彼は、散々私を批判した後で飴をくれた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>増える</ja> is "to increase" (as in, something just increases, you aren't doing the increasing yourself). This one is that one, where you're doing the increasing. So, this word means <vocabulary>to increase something</vocabulary>. You know you're doing the increasing because you said "yes" (<ja>やす</ja>) to increasing something, and did it yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same like <ja>増える</ja>. If you know that vocab word you probably can read this one as well.

context_sentences.en: I save all my homework for the weekend so I can spend more time with my family on weekdays.
context_sentences.ja: 平日に家族と過ごす時間を増やすために、宿題は全部週末にやることにしてるんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>solve</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to solve</vocabulary>. You know this verb is for when you are doing the solving because you think it's super <reading>coo</reading>' (<ja>く</ja>) to solve things.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>解ける</ja>, so if you know that you can read this one too.

context_sentences.en: I like solving puzzles.
context_sentences.ja: パズルを解くのが好きなんです。

context_sentences.en: That talented boy effortlessly solved difficult problems that even adults would find hard.
context_sentences.ja: その天才少年は、大人でも難しい難問をスラスラ解いた。

context_sentences.en: He said, "I can solve these problems in three minutes!" but after three weeks, he still hasn't sent me the answer.
context_sentences.ja: 「こんな問題、三分で解けるさ！」って言ってたのに、三週間たってもまだ解答が送られてこないんだよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cut off</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary>. Don't confuse this with <ja>断る</ja> which means "to refuse." You know this is <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> because of the <ja>つ</ja>, which hints that you have had <reading>two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>) too many chocolates, and it's time to cut you off.
data.reading_mnemonic: URGH! The reading isn't even the same as <ja>断る</ja>, how frustrating. <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> is read as <ja><reading>たつ</reading></ja>. Instead of eating too many chocolates and getting cut off, maybe you're eating too many tater <reading>tots</reading> (<ja>たつ</ja>). Don't eat so many of those, it's unhealthy. You have <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> tater tots from your diet so you don't get fat.

context_sentences.en: Take into account that you don’t know what you could do while you’re drunk, so you should really cut yourself off from drinking alcohol.
context_sentences.ja: 酔っぱらった時に何をしでかしたかを考慮すると、あなたは絶対にお酒を断つべきですよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Go ahead and <kanji>carry out</kanji> the task and <kanji>establish</kanji> the <vocabulary>institution</vocabulary>. To carry out and establish something is to institute it too. What do you institute? An institution.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know <ja>総理</ja> beforehand as well.

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab words <ja>朝</ja> and <ja>寝坊</ja> put together into one. So long as you know them separately you should know them together too!

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>応援</ja>. It's also just the on'yomi readings you learned.

data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the word <ja>大統領</ja> first, though.

data.meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>support</kanji> and <kanji>aid</kanji> is <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know <ja>観光</ja> as well.

context_sentences.en: The tourist had to pay $50 to get a doctor’s note in the U.S.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>男優</ja> was "actor"? Well, I bet you can extrapolate what this one means because it now has <kanji>woman</kanji> in it. This is an <vocabulary>actress</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A person who lives in a revolution (<ja>革命</ja>) <kanji>house</kanji> is <vocabulary>a revolutionary</vocabulary>. They want government change! They want to take down the people in power!

context_sentences.en: That revolutionary is only hot-tempered on the Internet.

context_sentences.en: If you want to be a revolutionary, first you need to be able to speak effectively.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>革</ja> is <kanji>leather</kanji> and <ja>ジャン</ja> is short for <ja>ジャンパー</ja> (Jumper, like a jacket). So, put those together and you have a <vocabulary>leather jacket</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the vocab word <ja>革</ja>, because this word is like two separate words put together (so it's treated as single words too, giving it that reading).

context_sentences.en: I’m not buying such an expensive leather jacket just because a fashionista told me to.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Long</kanji> <kanji>Cape</kanji> <kanji>Prefecture</kanji>. This will make more sense when you look at the reading. Hint: It's <vocabulary>Nagasaki Prefecture</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are <ja>長</ja> from <ja>長い</ja>, normal <ja>崎</ja> and normal <ja>県</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What is <kanji>real</kanji> is <kanji>right</kanji>. It is the <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>. It is also the <vocabulary>truth</vocabulary>. Don't believe anything that isn't <vocabulary>real</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>true</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Is that true?
context_sentences.ja: それは本当ですか？

context_sentences.en: I heard that these days university students write essays on their smart phones, but I wonder if that's true.
context_sentences.ja: さいきんの大学生はスマホでレポートをかくってきいたけど、本当かなあ。

context_sentences.en: I’m really awful at it.
context_sentences.ja: 本当に下手なのです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>本当</ja> is <kanji>reality</kanji> or <kanji>truth</kanji> (level 5 vocab). If you add on <ja>に</ja>, this changes the word to an adverb, and we get <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>truly</vocabulary>. <ja>本当に</ja>!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It shares the reading with the level 5 <ja>本当</ja> as well, but just has a particle on the end. Really!

context_sentences.en: Japanese people are really kind.
context_sentences.ja: 日本の人たちは、本当にやさしいです。

context_sentences.en: This product has gotten truly expensive.
context_sentences.ja: このせいひん、本当に高くなっちゃったねー。

context_sentences.en: Is this really the way?

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>呼ぶ</ja> is "to call" then this is something similar. This is when you are called by someone (and you're not doing the calling). This word is <vocabulary>to be called</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is shared with <ja>呼ぶ</ja>, so remember that and you'll be able to read this too.

context_sentences.en: I was a little sad to reach an age where I can be called a middle-aged woman.
context_sentences.ja: おばちゃんと呼ばれる年になってしまったことがちょっと悲しかった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is the transitive version of <ja>現れる</ja> (to appear), so rather than something appearing on its own, you’re making it appear. So this word means <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary>, but it’s usually used in set phrases like 姿を現す (to show up) or 正体を現す (to reveal one's true nature).
data.reading_mnemonic: Do you remember learning <ja>現れる</ja>? This has the same exact pronunciation!

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>alive</kanji> and the verb version means <vocabulary>to exist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be</vocabulary>, for anything that is alive and moving, like people and animals. 

The kanji isn't used too often for this word, so when you're writing just use the kana. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes so it's important to be able to recognize it!
data.reading_mnemonic: Do you know the word <ja>いる</ja>? This is the kanji version! If you've been studying Japanese up to this point you probably already know that word. You can associate these two things together into one and remember the reading at the same time!

data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

I am going <vocabulary>to obey</vocabulary> you. I think your order is a bit of <reading>shit <ja>が</ja></reading> (<ja>したが</ja>), I'll do it and obey you. 

(Little side note, did you know <ja>が</ja> in the middle of a sentence can mean "but" in Japanese? Think of it as that meaning here.)

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shake</kanji> and this verb is transitive, meaning that you're shaking something. So this verb means <vocabulary>to shake something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to wave something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to swing something</vocabulary>. You'll often see it paired with <ja>手</ja>, as in <ja>手を振る</ja>, meaning "to wave one's hand" or, as we'd usually say in English, simply "to wave".

This word can also be used when you shake someone off in the less physical way, as in <vocabulary>to break up with someone</vocabulary>.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

data.meaning_mnemonic:
<ja>触る</ja> means "to touch." This means <vocabulary>to feel</vocabulary>. It's kind of similar but somewhat different and also uses a different reading, making this word very hard in some ways. Just think how it's <reading>rare</reading> (<ja>れる</ja>) for you to feel anything at all, but this time you are, so that's nice, I guess.

The word also means <vocabulary>to touch on</vocabulary>, not in the physical sense, but when you touch on a subject. That's why it also means <vocabulary>to refer to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to mention</vocabulary>.

It's worth mentioning that this word is most often used with the particle <ja>に</ja>, so it's intransitive in Japanese. However, you'll also see it with the particle <ja>を</ja>, in which case it's considered transitive. The English translations are usually transitive, too.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is totally different from <ja>触る</ja> so don't let that fool you. In this case, you feel some <reading>fur</reading> (<ja>ふれ</ja>).

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned <ja>捕まる</ja> is "to be caught." Well this is the transitive version, so it means <vocabulary>to catch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to capture</vocabulary>. You (or someone else) is doing the catching, which is better than being the one who gets caught, I suppose.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is also not the same as <ja>捕まる</ja>. Sorry! It does have a similar reading to <ja>取る</ja> though, which also has to do with grabbing things (like grabbing onto an idea, for example). You can use <ja>取る</ja> as a jumping off point for remembering the reading of this word. You might also find it useful to think back to <ja>捉える</ja>, which has to do with mentally "catching" or "grasping" things. You'll sometimes see this written as <ja>捕らえる</ja> as well.

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but it's pretty easy. How do you read all the other "to climb" words? <ja><reading>登る</reading></ja> is one example. <ja><reading>上る</reading></ja> is another. They're all <ja>のぼる</ja>, and so is this. data.meaning_mnemonic: This word is pretty weird. It has two distinct sort of meanings. One is the "not so good" meaning, and the other is the "delicate" meaning. Lately the "not so good" meaning has taken priority, I think, so let's focus on that for now. Something is both <kanji>delicate</kanji> and <kanji>strange</kanji>. This delicate strange thing really is just <vocabulary>not so good</vocabulary>. It's not terrible, but it's not great either. It's just not so good. Why? Because if you touch it too hard, it will break. Also, it's not that normal either, so it's not helpful to you. Imagine a thing that could be like this, then think: Is this good? <vocabulary>not really</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>not so good</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>float</kanji>ing <kanji>world</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is what you call an <vocabulary>ukiyo-e woodblock print</vocabulary> in Japan. The "floating world" refers to an evanescent world that is impermanent (floating), just as beauty and entertainment is. Back in the day, this type of art was made into woodblock prints and paintings. Unfortunately, we don't have a name for these in English because they're so unique and special, but they come up more than you'd think, so get used to ukiyo-e!
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings don't really line up perfectly, but they're close (although mixed in terms of what has what reading). Take a look at the word and break everything down. <ja>浮</ja> takes the kun'yomi <ja>うき</ja> (from <ja>浮く</ja>), <ja>世</ja> also takes the kun'yomi <ja>よ</ja>, and then <ja>絵</ja> takes the on'yomi <ja>え</ja>. Put that all together and you have <ja>うきよえ</ja>! Or if you already know the word ukiyo-e, that works too!

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>visit</kanji> and the verb vocab version is also <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>.

What makes it different from <ja>訪ねる</ja>, though? With <ja>訪ねる</ja>, you're going somewhere or visiting someone with a clear purpose. With <ja>訪れる</ja>, the emphasis is on the act of visiting a place (and not a person), regardless of purpose. So, if you're simply saying that you're going to go visit the Kiyomizu Temple in Kyoto, you could say <ja>訪れる</ja>. On the other hand, if you're visiting the Kiyomizu Temple to discover something, or you're going to pay a visit to a teacher in Kyoto for some advice, you could use <ja>訪ねる</ja>.

Those uses we just described for <ja>訪れる</ja> are for when it is transitive. However, it can also be intransitive, if the action is done by something rather than someone. In that case, it means "to come", as in "winter comes" (<ja>冬が訪れる</ja>) or "peace comes" (<ja>平和が訪れる</ja>). <ja>訪ねる</ja>, on the other hand, cannot be used in this way.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading isn't the same as <ja>訪ねる</ja>, though, I'm afraid. It's <ja>おとず</ja>. Remember how this means just visiting a place? Unfortunately, you completely forgot what you were visiting. When you finally remember, it's because you were looking down to think. It's to look at the toes of the giant Buddha statue. "<reading>Oh Toes</reading>!" (<ja>おとず</ja>), you exclaim.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>detach</kanji>, but what happens when something detaches? It causes it <vocabulary>to separate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to leave</vocabulary>. This refers to when something separates on its own. You aren't doing the separating. You know this because it's <reading>rare</reading> (<ja>れる</ja>) to see things separate, but sometimes you do see them. Also, whenever you see <ja>れる</ja> usually it's a safe bet that you're not the one doing the action, right? Think about it.
data.reading_mnemonic: For the reading, think about what is separating. It's quite sad, because all of the <ja><reading>花</reading></ja>s (<ja>はな</ja>) are separating from their stems and falling on the ground, and nobody knows why. Just falling off and being sad.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the <vocabulary>how many</vocabulary> meaning. You know this because you ask "how many" and they answer "<ja><reading>つ</reading></ja>." This can also be used to ask <vocabulary>how old</vocabulary> someone is, but generally only for children's ages.

This word is usually written in kana in modern writing.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji, nice job.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>How many</kanji>? <kanji>What</kanji>? In this area of <kanji>study</kanji>, you ask these questions a lot. This area of study is <vocabulary>geometry</vocabulary>, because you have to ask how many sides and how much the area is or something (can you tell I don't remember any maths?).
data.reading_mnemonic: The <ja>学</ja> is read correctly, in terms of what you learned. The <ja>幾</ja> and <ja>何</ja> is weird, though. Just think how when you're asking a question in Japanese, you end the sentence with <ja>か</ja>. So, it's like, "<ja>何か</ja>????" and that's why it becomes <ja>か</ja>. Then, for <ja>幾</ja> think about how the <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) to answering geometry questions correctly is figuring out "how many" sides something has. So, "do you have the <reading>key</reading><ja><reading>か</reading></ja>?"
